questions.text: Which of the following deficiency causes xerophthalmia and follicular hyperkeratosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:

 

  • Xerophthalmia: This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.

 

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis: This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.

 

 

Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:

 

  • Night blindness
  • Immunosuppression: Leading to increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium, increasing the risk of infections in these areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin: Deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

 

Option C. Biotin: Deficiency can cause dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Deficiency can cause anemia, dermatitis, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Transfer objects from one hand to another

questions.text: Identify the milestone shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transfer objects from one hand to another

 

The milestone shown in the image, where the child appears to be manipulating an object, is indicative of the ability to transfer objects from one hand to another. This skill typically develops around 6 months of age and is an important indicator of emerging fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bidextrous approach: Refers to the ability to use both hands to pick an object, which typically develops by 4 months. This involves reaching for objects with both hands but does not necessarily involve the transfer of objects between hands.

 

Option C. Hand regard: This milestone, where an infant looks at and examines their own hand, typically occurs around 3 months of age. The image does not depict this behavior.

 

Option D. Hands come in midline: By around 4 months, infants begin to bring their hands together in the midline of their body. This is a precursor to more complex hand movements but is not what is shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

By around 6 months of age, infants typically develop the ability to transfer objects from one hand to another, demonstrating emerging fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

questions.text: Longitudinal growth of a long bone is most likely affected by a fracture involving which of the following regions? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate


The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate, is a layer of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis (end) and the metaphysis of a long bone. This plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones during childhood and adolescence. Active cell division occurs here, which contributes to the lengthening of the bone. Any damage or fracture at the epiphyseal plate can disrupt this growth process, leading to potential growth abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone but is not directly responsible for bone growth. Fractures here do not significantly impact the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Option B. Metaphysis: The metaphysis is the flared part of the bone between the diaphysis and the epiphyseal plate. Although it plays a role in supporting growth, fractures here do not directly disrupt the longitudinal growth as much as a fracture at the epiphyseal plate would.

 

Option C. Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the shaft or central part of the long bone. Fractures in the diaphysis typically affect the strength and integrity of the bone but do not interfere with growth lengthwise.

 

Educational Objective:


The epiphyseal plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones, and fractures here can significantly impact this process.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the superficial parotid gland on FNAC? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy

 

The preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the parotid gland, as confirmed by fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), is:

 

This is the treatment of choice for a benign parotid tumors like pleomorphic adenoma. It involves the surgical removal of the entire superficial lobe. Enucleation or simple excision is avoided as the tumor has projections (pseudopodia) which may be left behind leading to recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide local incision: This is not typically performed for benign parotid tumors. However, now a days it is becoming an alternate to superficial parotidectomy.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as they are typically not responsive to chemotherapy agents.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as it is generally reserved for cancer treatment and not indicated for benign conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Superficial parotidectomy is the preferred treatment for a benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma, providing targeted removal of the entire superficial lobe.

questions.text: A skin rash gets exaggerated on sun exposure is repaired by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair

 

 

Exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays from the sun causes damage to DNA by inducing the formation of thymidine dimers, which are covalent linkages between adjacent thymine bases on a DNA strand. These dimers distort the DNA structure, interfering with replication and transcription.

 

Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the primary mechanism used by cells to repair this type of damage. The NER pathway identifies the bulky lesions caused by thymidine dimers, excises the damaged section of DNA, and fills in the gap with the correct nucleotides using a DNA polymerase.

 

A defect in this repair mechanism can lead to xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV light, leading to severe sunburns, rashes, and a high risk of skin cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair: This mechanism repairs small, non-bulky DNA lesions such as single-base alterations, including deamination and oxidative damage. It does not correct UV-induced thymidine dimers.

 

Option B. Double-stranded DNA break repair: This repair mechanism is involved in fixing double-strand breaks, which occur due to radiation, replication errors, or certain chemicals. It does not address thymidine dimers.

 

Option C. Mismatch repair: Mismatch repair corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as incorrect base pairing (e.g., A-C instead of A-T). It is not involved in repairing damage from UV light exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleotide excision repair is the primary DNA repair mechanism that corrects damage caused by UV light, such as thymidine dimers.

choices.text: Placental site trophoblastic tumor
Invasive mole

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial mole

 

Explanation:

 

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) includes a spectrum of conditions characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation. These conditions are broadly classified into molar and non-molar trophoblastic diseases.

 

  • Hydatidiform Mole:
    • Complete Mole
    • Partial Mole
    • Invasive Mole
  • Non-Molar Trophoblastic Diseases:
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
    • Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN), on the other hand, includes only the malignant forms of trophoblastic disease:

 

  1. Invasive Mole
  2. Choriocarcinoma
  3. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
  4. Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

A partial mole is a type of hydatidiform mole and is considered benign. It is not included under GTN as it does not have malignant potential unless it transforms into an invasive mole, which is rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Choriocarcinoma: This is a malignant form of GTD and is classified under GTN.

 

Option C. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor: This is another malignant form of GTD and is included under GTN.

 

Option D. Invasive Mole: An invasive mole is a malignant transformation of a hydatidiform mole and is included under GTN.

 

Educational Objective

 

Partial moles are not classified as gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) because they are generally benign and non-malignant.

 

Ref: Page no 615, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: What is the name for the association of intraocular hemorrhage with subarachnoid hemorrhage? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Terson’s Syndrome

 

Terson syndrome refers to the combination of bilateral intraocular hemorrhages (including intraretinal, subhyaloid, and vitreous hemorrhage) associated with subarachnoid hemorrhage due to aneurysmal rupture. This condition represents a significant ophthalmological manifestation of intracranial bleeding events.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Duane's Syndrome: This is a congenital eye movement disorder characterized by limited abduction, adduction, or both, with narrowing of the palpebral fissure and retraction of the globe on adduction. It has no relation to hemorrhage.

 

Options C. Brown's Syndrome: This is a restriction of elevation of the eye in adduction due to a problem with the superior oblique tendon sheath complex. It is not related to hemorrhagic conditions.

 

Options D. Tolosa Hunt Syndrome: This is a painful ophthalmoplegia caused by nonspecific inflammation of the cavernous sinus or superior orbital fissure. It is not associated with intraocular or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Terson syndrome represents a critical ocular manifestation of subarachnoid hemorrhage, specifically featuring intraocular hemorrhages in association with aneurysmal rupture, which serves as an important diagnostic sign of intracranial bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following signs and symptoms is not highly specific for iron deficiency? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Macroglossia

 

Explanation:

 

Macroglossia (abnormally enlarged tongue) is not a specific finding in iron deficiency anemia. It occurs instead in conditions like amyloidosis, hypothyroidism, and certain genetic disorders such as Down syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pagophagia (ice eating): This specific form of pica is highly characteristic of iron deficiency. The craving and consumption of ice is a well-recognized manifestation that strongly suggests iron deficiency when present.

 

Option B. Koilonychia ("spoon nails"): These thin, concave nails with raised edges develop gradually in chronic iron deficiency anemia and serve as a helpful diagnostic sign when present.

 

Option C. Blue Sclera: The bluish discoloration of the sclera occurs in advanced iron deficiency due to thinning of collagen, which allows the underlying choroidal veins to become visible. This finding strongly points to significant iron deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pagophagia, koilonychia, and blue sclera are recognized clinical manifestations of iron deficiency anemia, while macroglossia is not part of this clinical picture and suggests alternative diagnoses.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Noonan Syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abnormal Karyotype

 

Noonan Syndrome has a normal karyotype, which makes option D incorrect. This syndrome is characterized by multiple congenital abnormalities but does not involve chromosomal abnormalities that would be visible on a standard karyotype analysis. Noonan Syndrome is actually a genetic disorder caused by mutations in various genes in the RAS-MAPK pathway, but these mutations are at the gene level rather than visible chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short Stature: Correct statement. Short stature is a common clinical feature of Noonan Syndrome. Affected individuals typically have growth issues and remain shorter than average.

 

Option B. Webbed Neck: Correct statement. Webbed neck (pterygium colli) is a distinctive physical characteristic of Noonan Syndrome. This feature involves excess skin on the neck creating a webbed appearance similar to what is seen in Turner Syndrome.

 

Option C. Low Posterior Hairline: Correct statement. A low posterior hairline is another typical physical feature of Noonan Syndrome. This refers to hair growth that extends unusually low on the back of the neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noonan Syndrome presents with distinctive physical features including short stature, webbed neck, and low posterior hairline, but has a normal karyotype, distinguishing it from chromosomal disorders like Turner Syndrome which may present with similar physical characteristics but show chromosomal abnormalities on karyotype analysis.

questions.text: Patient came with fever, rash and eschar formation. On examination, mite bite was also present. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support this diagnosis are:

 

  1. The presence of eschar, which is a common finding in scrub typhus and anthrax.
  2. The mite bite, which is the biggest clue provided, as scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers).
  3. The explanation that among the rickettsial diseases mentioned in the options (scrub typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and epidemic typhus), only scrub typhus is transmitted by mites.

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites, commonly known as chiggers.

 

Triad – Eschar; Regional lymphadenopathy and Maculopapular rash

 

 

 

 

*Coxiella and  Bartonella  are now excluded from this family

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthrax: Anthrax is caused by the bacteria Bacillus anthracis and is not transmitted by mite bites. It is a zoonotic disease acquired through contact with infected animals or their products, inhalation of spores, or ingestion of contaminated food.

 

Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever: This is another rickettsial disease, but it is transmitted by ticks, not mites. The presence of a mite bite in the given scenario rules out this option.

 

Option D. Epidemic Typhus: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by lice, epidemic typhus presents with a rash but does not typically include eschar formation, nor is it associated with mite bites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers). The presence of eschar, fever, rash, and a mite bite are key clinical features suggestive of this diagnosis.

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

 

Retinal detachment occurs when the sensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This separation can be due to a retinal break, known as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which is the most common type. In patients with high myopia, there is an increased risk of peripheral retinal degeneration, leading to retinal holes that can progress to retinal detachment. The presence of floaters and flashes is a key symptom indicating retinal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with sudden severe headache and neurological symptoms rather than visual symptoms like floaters.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: While this can cause floaters, it is more commonly associated with trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or vascular abnormalities rather than high myopia.

 

Option D. Branched retinal artery occlusion: This condition usually presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in part of the visual field rather than floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

 

  • More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement:
    • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Labor Care Guide (LCG), active labor begins at more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The older definition of active labor was at 4 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) now defines active labor as beginning at more than 6 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • Complete effacement indicates that the cervix has thinned out, which is a key indicator of active labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination: This indicates that the fetal head is still high in the pelvis and not yet engaged. It does not determine active labor.

 

Option B. Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes: This frequency and duration of contractions are not sufficient to determine active labor. Active labor typically involves regular, strong contractions lasting 45-60 seconds and occurring every 2-3 minutes.

 

Option D. Rupture of membranes: While rupture of membranes can occur during labor, it is not a definitive indicator of active labor. Cervical dilation and effacement are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active labor is determined by more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation with complete effacement, according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Ref: Page no 138, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia


Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a patient with metabolic syndrome predisposes to hyperglycemia. Metabolic syndrome is characterized by insulin resistance, often seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and, in some cases, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Insulin resistance impairs the body’s ability to utilize glucose efficiently. When TPN, which is high in glucose, is administered, the already compromised insulin response leads to elevated blood glucose levels, resulting in hyperglycemia. This is a common complication in patients receiving TPN, especially those with underlying metabolic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reactive Hypoglycemia: Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose levels drop excessively after eating, due to an overproduction of insulin. It is not typically associated with TPN or metabolic syndrome, as TPN administration generally leads to hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: While hyperlipidemia is a component of metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct complication specifically associated with TPN. Although TPN can contain lipids, its primary complication related to metabolic syndrome is hyperglycemia due to glucose intolerance.

 

Option D. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia, characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, can be associated with metabolic syndrome but is not directly induced by TPN administration. The primary metabolic disturbance from TPN in these patients is related to glucose management rather than uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I
Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II
Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II
Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

questions.text: Following ovulation, the oocyte remains halted in which meiotic phase until fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

 

After ovulation, the oocyte that is released is the secondary oocyte, which is arrested in metaphase II of meiosis. This arrest continues until fertilization occurs. During fertilization, the entry of sperm triggers the completion of meiosis II, leading to the formation of a mature ovum and the release of the second polar body.

 

This arrest in metaphase II is a crucial step in the reproductive cycle, ensuring that the oocyte is ready to complete meiosis only if fertilization occurs, which prevents the wasteful completion of meiosis without fertilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I: This phase describes the primary oocyte that is arrested in prophase I during fetal development and remains in this state until puberty. It is not involved in the post-ovulation phase.

 

Option B. Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II: This option is incorrect because the secondary oocyte does not complete prophase II. It arrests in metaphase II after ovulation and only completes meiosis II if fertilization occurs.

 

Option C. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II: This is incorrect because the primary oocyte does not arrest in prophase II. It arrests in prophase I, and after puberty, it resumes meiosis to form a secondary oocyte.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II at the time of ovulation and remains in this stage until fertilization occurs, highlighting a critical regulatory checkpoint in the female reproductive cycle.

choices.text: Not related to the incubation period

questions.text: In the context of a communicable disease, when the maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period, what is the relationship between the generation time and the incubation period? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Shorter than the incubation period

 

  • Generation time is defined as "the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host." 
  • When maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period (before symptoms appear), the generation time must be shorter than the incubation period, as the incubation period extends from infection until the first appearance of symptoms. 
  • Though generation time is generally roughly equal to incubation period, this specific scenario describes a situation where maximum infectivity precedes symptom onset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Longer than the incubation period: This would only be true if maximal infectivity occurred after the appearance of symptoms (after the incubation period ended), but the question specifically states maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period.

 

Option C. Equal to the incubation period: While generation time is roughly equal to the incubation period in many diseases, this does not apply when maximal infectivity occurs before the end of the incubation period, as specified in the question.

 

Option D. Not related to the incubation period: These concepts are clearly related. Generation time and incubation period are related concepts in infectious disease epidemiology, with specific temporal relationships.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time measures the interval from infection to maximal infectivity, while incubation period measures time from infection to symptom onset. Their relationship varies by disease, but when maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period, generation time must be shorter than incubation period.

questions.text: Mobius syndrome in a fetus may be caused by the maternal intake of which of the following medications? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol

 

Misoprostol has been clearly documented as causing Mobius sequency in fetuses when mothers take it during pregnancy. This condition is characterized by facial palsy and limb abnormalities. The teratogenic effect specifically affects cranial nerve development, resulting in the characteristic facial paralysis seen in Mobius syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: While mifepristone is used for medical abortion, it has not been associated with Mobius syndrome specifically. It functions primarily as a progesterone receptor antagonist rather than causing cranial nerve developmental defects.

 

Option C. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone (prostaglandin E2) is not linked to Mobius syndrome. It is commonly used for cervical ripening and labor induction but lacks the specific teratogenic effect on cranial nerve development that would lead to Mobius syndrome.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is associated with craniosynostosis (clover leaf skull) but not with Mobius syndrome. As a folic acid antagonist, methotrexate affects rapidly dividing cells and can cause various congenital abnormalities, but Mobius syndrome is not among them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Misoprostol exposure during pregnancy can cause Mobius syndrome (facial palsy and limb abnormalities), making it crucial to avoid during early fetal development.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with colicky pain. Following type of crystals were found on urine examination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystinuria

 

The urine examination shows hexagonal crystals, which are characteristic of cystine crystals. These crystals are pathognomonic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder that affects the renal reabsorption of dibasic amino acids, including cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. Cystinuria leads to the formation of cystine stones in the kidneys, bladder, and ureters, often presenting with colicky pain due to stone obstruction.

 

Cystine crystals appear as flat, hexagonal plates, which is a distinctive feature that helps differentiate them from other types of crystals seen in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ADPKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): This condition involves the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney enlargement and dysfunction. It does not typically present with hexagonal crystals in the urine; the crystals seen are more commonly calcium oxalate.

 

Option B. Calcium oxalate stones: These stones are among the most common kidney stones and appear as envelope or dumbbell-shaped crystals, not hexagonal. They are usually related to hyperoxaluria and not cystinuria.

 

Option D. Glomerulonephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys, leading to symptoms like hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension. It does not present with specific crystals like the hexagonal cystine crystals seen in cystinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hexagonal cystine crystals in urine are characteristic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder affecting the renal absorption of certain amino acids, leading to recurrent cystine stone formation.

choices.text: They are made up of bacteria and virus
They can be cultured in cell-free media

questions.text: Which of the following statements about prions is true? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. They are infectious proteins

 

Explanation:


Prions are infectious proteins without any nucleic acid. These proteinaceous infectious particles are responsible for transmissible spongiform encephalopathies. Unlike conventional pathogens, prions consist solely of abnormally folded proteins that can induce normal proteins to also misfold, creating a self-propagating infectious agent without genetic material.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. They are made up of bacteria and virus - This is incorrect. Prions are not composed of bacteria or viruses. They are misfolded proteins with no cellular or viral components. Bacteria are complete prokaryotic cells with cell walls and genetic material, while viruses contain nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein coat. Prions lack both cellular structures and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. They have rich nuclear material - This is incorrect. Prions completely lack nucleic acids (DNA or RNA), which distinguishes them from all other infectious agents. They are purely protein in nature with no genetic material whatsoever.

 

Option D. They can be cultured in cell-free media - This is incorrect. Prions cannot be cultivated on cell-free media because they lack the metabolic machinery for self-replication. Unlike bacteria which can grow on nutrient media, prions require host cellular machinery to propagate. They replicate by converting normal proteins to the pathogenic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prions represent a unique class of infectious agents consisting solely of misfolded proteins without nucleic acids, challenging the central dogma that transmission of biological information requires DNA or RNA.

choices.text: It is caused by Burkholderia mallei.
It is endemic to Southeast Asia.
It can present similarly to Pulmonary Tuberculosis.
The bacterium is considered a potential biowarfare agent.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning Melioidosis is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (It is caused by Burkholderia mallei).

 

Explanation:

Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, not Burkholderia mallei. B. pseudomallei is a saprophyte found in soil and water in endemic regions. It causes a disease called melioidosis which has been nicknamed the "Vietnam time-bomb disease" due to its ability to remain latent for many years before activating. B. mallei, on the other hand, is a strictly zoonotic pathogen that causes glanders and farcy in horses and other equids.

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is endemic to Southeast Asia - This statement is true. Melioidosis is endemic to Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore and northern Australia. The bacterium B. pseudomallei is found in soil and water in these regions, where environmental conditions favor its survival.

 

Option C. It can present similarly to Pulmonary Tuberculosis - This statement is true. One of the clinical presentations of melioidosis is sub-acute pulmonary infection that can range from mild bronchitis to severe tuberculosis-like pneumonia. This tuberculosis-like presentation is one reason why melioidosis is often called "the great mimicker" in endemic regions.

Option D. The bacterium is considered a potential biowarfare agent - This statement is true. B. pseudomallei is classified as a potential agent of biological warfare due to its environmental persistence, relatively low infectious dose when aerosolized, resistance to many common antibiotics, and the serious nature of the disease it causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei (not B. mallei), can present with a variety of clinical manifestations from acute septicemia to chronic suppurative infections, and requires prolonged antibiotic therapy typically consisting of an intensive phase with ceftazidime or a carbapenem followed by an extended eradication phase with oral antibiotics.

questions.text: A physician wanted to perform plasma glucose estimation using the vacutainer shown in the image. Which of the following is the anticoagulant used for this test? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Potassium oxalate

 

  • Potassium oxalate is commonly used in vacutainers for plasma glucose estimation because it acts as both an anticoagulant and it prevents clotting by binding calcium in the blood. We presume that the examiner by mistake showed the blue topped vacutainer in place of the gray one. However let us review that blue-topped vacutainer contains Trisodium citrate while the gray-topped vacutainer contains Potassium oxalate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisodium Citrate: Used primarily as an anticoagulant in blood collection tubes for coagulation studies, not suitable for glucose estimation because it does not prevent glycolysis effectively.

 

Option C. Sodium fluoride: Also a glycolysis inhibitor and commonly used with an anticoagulant (potassium oxalate) in glucose testing..

 

Option D. EDTA: Mainly used as an anticoagulant in hematology tests. While it effectively prevents blood clots, it does not inhibit glycolysis, making it unsuitable for glucose tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For accurate plasma glucose estimation, potassium oxalate and enolase is used because it effectively prevents blood clotting and preserves glucose by inhibiting glycolysis respectively. 

 

Always use a grey-top tube (NaF/KOx) when measuring plasma glucose to prevent post-collection glycolysis and falsely low results.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the dermatological condition shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation

 

The dermatological condition shown in the image is characterized by a photosensitive rash. This type of rash typically occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the face, neck, and hands. The condition depicted is pellagra, which is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin). Pellagra is associated with the "4 Ds": diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis, and death. The dermatitis in pellagra is often photosensitive, meaning it worsens with exposure to sunlight, which explains the rash seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Deficiency in Vitamin A leads to conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia (dry eyes), not photosensitive rashes.

 

Option B. Vitamin B1: Deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine) causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, not the skin.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C results in scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, and joint pain, but not typically photosensitive rashes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with a photosensitive rash among other symptoms like diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis.

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 54-year-old woman, underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation.
  •  Lymphedema is a common complication of breast cancer surgery, particularly when lymph nodes are removed or damaged during the procedure, leading to poor drainage of lymphatic fluid from the affected arm.
  • The swelling in lymphedema is usually painless, and the skin may feel tight or heavy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphangiosarcoma:  Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that can develop in the lymphatic vessels, often years after radiation therapy or surgery for breast cancer. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and skin changes in the affected area. However, it is a very uncommon complication compared to lymphedema.

 

Option C. Venous thrombosis: Venous thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in a vein, usually presenting with symptoms like swelling, pain, and warmth in the affected area. In this case, the swelling is painless and is more indicative of lymphatic fluid accumulation rather than a venous thrombosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissues, presenting with symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and warmth. The absence of warmth, redness, and tenderness in the patient's presentation makes cellulitis an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema is a common postoperative complication of breast cancer surgery due to the removal or damage of lymph nodes, leading to poor lymphatic drainage.
  •  It presents as painless swelling, heaviness, and skin thickening in the affected limb.

questions.text: Heme is derived from which of the following amino acids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Explanation:

 

Heme is derived from glycine, which is one of the simplest amino acids. Despite its simplicity, glycine is a precursor to several important biological compounds. In the heme biosynthesis pathway, glycine combines with succinyl-CoA to form δ-aminolevulinic acid, which is the first step in the synthesis of heme. Heme is a critical component of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various cytochromes, playing a vital role in oxygen transport and cellular respiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved in various metabolic processes, including the synthesis of nucleotides and amino sugars, but it does not contribute directly to heme biosynthesis.

 

Option C. Glutamate: Glutamate is a key neurotransmitter and is involved in the synthesis of glutathione and other amino acids but not directly in heme formation.

 

Option D. Valine: Valine is a branched-chain amino acid important in protein synthesis and energy metabolism but not in the biosynthesis of heme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Products of amino acids -

  • Tryptophan – Niacin, serotonin, melatonin
  • Tyrosine - Melanin, catecholamine, thyroxin
  • Histidine – Histamine, Carnosine, Anserine
  • Glycine- Creatine, Glutathione, Haem, Porphyrin, Glyoxylate, Choline, Betaine, serine, Sarcosine

Glutathione – tripeptide →  Glutamate, Cysteine & Glycine

Creatine- made from 3 AA → Arginine, Methionine & Glycine

  • Serine → Glycine, Selenocysteine, Phosphatidyl serine, Sphingosine (Serine + Palmitoyl CoA)
  • Arginine - NO, Creatine, Urea & Ornithine
